| A gnoll matriarch:* has [a head, a couple of arms, and a torso](/wiki/Humanoid "Humanoid").
* can [see invisible creatures](/wiki/See_invisible "See invisible").
* is [poisonous](/wiki/Poisonous "Poisonous") to eat.
* is [carnivorous](/wiki/Carnivore "Carnivore").
* is not a valid [polymorphable](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") form.
* is a giant.
* is normally generated [hostile](/wiki/Hostile "Hostile").
* [likes gold](/wiki/Gold_lover "Gold lover").
* likes gems.
* can pick up weapons and food.
* can pick up [magical items](/wiki/Magical_item "Magical item").
* has [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision").
* appears only in [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom"). |                                                                                     |

A **gnoll matriarch**, H, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack") and [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack"). The gnoll matriarch is a [carnivorous](/wiki/Carnivorous "Carnivorous") [giant](/wiki/Giant_\(monster_attribute\) "Giant (monster attribute)") [demihuman](/wiki/Demihuman "Demihuman") [gnoll](/wiki/Gnoll#dNetHack "Gnoll") that has [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision"), can [see invisible](/wiki/See_invisible "See invisible"), and will seek out [gold](/wiki/Gold "Gold"), [gems](/wiki/Gem "Gem") and various other items to pick up. Though gnoll matriarchs are considered giants, they lack the [boulder](/wiki/Boulder "Boulder")-throwing [strength](/wiki/Strong "Strong") of other giants.

A gnoll matriarch has the ability to cast [monster spells](/wiki/Monster_spell "Monster spell") clerically, followed by a bite attack - her clerical spells include [blind](/wiki/Blind_\(monster_spell\) "Blind (monster spell)"), [paralyze](/wiki/Paralyze_\(monster_spell\) "Paralyze (monster spell)"), [confusion](/wiki/Confuse_\(monster_spell\) "Confuse (monster spell)"), [open wounds](/wiki/Open_wounds "Open wounds"), and the ability to cast [mass cure allies](/index.php?title=Mass_cure_allies\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Mass cure allies (page does not exist)") at range. She can also summon [gnolls](/wiki/Gnoll_\(dNetHack\) "Gnoll (dNetHack)") intermittently: there is a 1⁄20 chance of a gnoll matriarch generating one during each of her turns if you are nearby and in line of sight, which also respects [extinction](/wiki/Extinction "Extinction").

A gnoll matriarch [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") is [poisonous](/wiki/Poisonous "Poisonous") to [eat](/wiki/Eat "Eat").

## Generation

Gnoll matriarchs are always created hostile, and are only randomly generated in [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom"). They are not a valid form for normal [polymorph](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph").

Ten gnoll matriarchs are randomly placed around [the lair of Yeenoghu](/wiki/User:Chris/dNetHack/Branches/Lord_Levels#Yeenoghu.2C_Demon_Lord_of_Gnolls_and_Ghouls "User:Chris/dNetHack/Branches/Lord Levels") at level creation, and they also make up 1⁄20 of the monsters randomly generated there.

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Gnole](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gnole "wikipedia:Gnole")***

The gnoll is a creature that appears in various types of fantasy media, and is generally portrayed as a human-hyena hybrid or a form of humanoid hyena. The term originates from 1912 short story collection *[The Book of Wonder](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Book_of_Wonder "wikipedia:The Book of Wonder")* by [Lord Dunsany](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lord_Dunsany "wikipedia:Lord Dunsany"), with one short story titled "How Nuth Would Have Practised His Art upon the Gnoles".

The gnoll of *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")* is introduced in [the first boxed set](https://archive.org/details/monsters_and_treasures/page/7/mode/2up) of the game, and gnolls are described in *Book 2: Monsters and Treasure* as a "cross between [Gnomes](/wiki/Gnome "Gnome") and [Trolls](/wiki/Troll "Troll") (...perhaps, Lord Sunsany did not really make it all that clear)". These early gnolls were stated to be similar to hobgoblins with +2 morale, while a gnoll king and his bodyguard fought similar to trolls without regenerative power. The 1st Monster Manual for *Advanced Dungeons & Dragons* and all subsequent material describe gnolls as aggressive desert-dwelling nomads that resemble humanoid hyenas, and actively raid and plunder other settlements; it also introduces [Yeenoghu](/wiki/Yeenoghu "Yeenoghu"), the demon god of gnolls who many of them serve and worship.

## Encyclopedia entry

We are born and we die.  
No one cares, no one remembers,  
and it doesn't matter.  
This is why we laugh.  
\[ The Gnoll Credo, by J. Stanton ]

- *This page is a **[stub](/wiki/Category:Stubs "Category:Stubs")**. Should you wish to do so, you can contribute by [**expanding this page**.](https://nethackwiki.com/index.php?title=Gnoll_matriarch\&action=edit)*

[![This article describes a 3.4.3-based variant of NetHack. Click here for more information.](/images/5/5d/Nh343var-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article describes a 3.4.3-based variant of NetHack. Click here for more information.")
html:
Gnoll matriarch

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
H gnoll matriarch
Difficulty 12
Attacks Cast 0d0 clerical spell, Bite 3d2 physical
H gnoll matriarch
Difficulty 12
Attacks

Cast 0d0 clerical spell, Bite 3d2 physical

Base level 10
Base experience 261
Speed 3
Base AC 5
Base MR 10
Alignment -5 (chaotic)
Frequency (by normal means) 0 (Not randomly generated)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 3000
Nutritional value 1000
Size large
Resistances none
Resistances conveyed none

A gnoll matriarch:

  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • can see invisible creatures.
  • is poisonous to eat.
  • is carnivorous.
  • is not a valid polymorphable form.
  • is a giant.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • likes gold.
  • likes gems.
  • can pick up weapons and food.
  • can pick up magical items.
  • has infravision.
  • appears only in Gehennom.

A gnoll matriarch, H, is a type of monster that appears in dNetHack and notdNetHack. The gnoll matriarch is a carnivorous giant demihuman gnoll that has infravision, can see invisible, and will seek out gold, gems and various other items to pick up. Though gnoll matriarchs are considered giants, they lack the boulder-throwing strength of other giants.

A gnoll matriarch has the ability to cast monster spells clerically, followed by a bite attack - her clerical spells include blind, paralyze, confusion, open wounds, and the ability to cast mass cure allies at range. She can also summon gnolls intermittently: there is a 1⁄20 chance of a gnoll matriarch generating one during each of her turns if you are nearby and in line of sight, which also respects extinction.

A gnoll matriarch corpse is poisonous to eat.

Generation

Gnoll matriarchs are always created hostile, and are only randomly generated in Gehennom. They are not a valid form for normal polymorph.

Ten gnoll matriarchs are randomly placed around the lair of Yeenoghu at level creation, and they also make up 1⁄20 of the monsters randomly generated there.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Gnole

The gnoll is a creature that appears in various types of fantasy media, and is generally portrayed as a human-hyena hybrid or a form of humanoid hyena. The term originates from 1912 short story collection The Book of Wonder by Lord Dunsany, with one short story titled "How Nuth Would Have Practised His Art upon the Gnoles".

The gnoll of Dungeons & Dragons is introduced in the first boxed set of the game, and gnolls are described in Book 2: Monsters and Treasure as a "cross between Gnomes and Trolls (...perhaps, Lord Sunsany did not really make it all that clear)". These early gnolls were stated to be similar to hobgoblins with +2 morale, while a gnoll king and his bodyguard fought similar to trolls without regenerative power. The 1st Monster Manual for Advanced Dungeons & Dragons and all subsequent material describe gnolls as aggressive desert-dwelling nomads that resemble humanoid hyenas, and actively raid and plunder other settlements; it also introduces Yeenoghu, the demon god of gnolls who many of them serve and worship.

Encyclopedia entry

We are born and we die.
No one cares, no one remembers,
and it doesn't matter.
This is why we laugh.
[ The Gnoll Credo, by J. Stanton ]

This page is a stub. Should you wish to do so, you can contribute by expanding this page.

A '''gnoll matriarch''', {{gray|H}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in [[dNetHack]] and [[notdNetHack]]. The gnoll matriarch is a [[carnivorous]] [[Giant (monster attribute)|giant]] [[demihuman]] [[Gnoll#dNetHack|gnoll]] that has [[infravision]], can [[see invisible]], and will seek out [[gold]], [[gem]]s and various other items to pick up. Though gnoll matriarchs are considered giants, they lack the [[boulder]]-throwing [[Strong|strength]] of other giants.

A gnoll matriarch has the ability to cast [[monster spell]]s clerically, followed by a bite attack - her clerical spells include [[Blind (monster spell)|blind]], [[Paralyze (monster spell)|paralyze]], [[Confuse (monster spell)|confusion]], [[open wounds]], and the ability to cast [[mass cure allies]] at range. She can also summon [[Gnoll (dNetHack)|gnolls]] intermittently: there is a {{frac|20}} chance of a gnoll matriarch generating one during each of her turns if you are nearby and in line of sight, which also respects [[extinction]].

A gnoll matriarch [[corpse]] is [[poisonous]] to [[eat]].

==Generation==
Gnoll matriarchs are always created hostile, and are only randomly generated in [[Gehennom]]. They are not a valid form for normal [[polymorph]].

Ten gnoll matriarchs are randomly placed around [[User:Chris/dNetHack/Branches/Lord Levels#Yeenoghu, Demon Lord of Gnolls and Ghouls|the lair of Yeenoghu]] at level creation, and they also make up {{frac|20}} of the monsters randomly generated there.

==Origin==
{{wikipedia|Gnole}}
The gnoll is a creature that appears in various types of fantasy media, and is generally portrayed as a human-hyena hybrid or a form of humanoid hyena. The term originates from 1912 short story collection ''[[wikipedia:The Book of Wonder|The Book of Wonder]]'' by [[wikipedia:Lord Dunsany|Lord Dunsany]], with one short story titled "How Nuth Would Have Practised His Art upon the Gnoles".

The gnoll of ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'' is introduced in [https://archive.org/details/monsters_and_treasures/page/7/mode/2up the first boxed set] of the game, and gnolls are described in ''Book 2: Monsters and Treasure'' as a "cross between [[Gnome]]s and [[Troll]]s (...perhaps, Lord Sunsany did not really make it all that clear)". These early gnolls were stated to be similar to hobgoblins with +2 morale, while a gnoll king and his bodyguard fought similar to trolls without regenerative power. The 1st Monster Manual for ''Advanced Dungeons & Dragons'' and all subsequent material describe gnolls as aggressive desert-dwelling nomads that resemble humanoid hyenas, and actively raid and plunder other settlements; it also introduces [[Yeenoghu]], the demon god of gnolls who many of them serve and worship.
